Crypto group protests court order to freeze trucker convoy accounts — says it ‘cannot’ freeze money or prevent it from being movedJacob Lorinc1/22/2022

Independent experts say cryptocurrency group Nunchuck appears to be correct — it does not have the power to control digital wallets or access what’s inside.

Nunchuckarc cov economy, arc cov recovery, cryto, freedom convoy, convoy protests Canada, Loonie, cryptocurrency, Bitcoin, Ottawa, Nunchuck, KMI1, smg_business, InHouseArticle_thestar, starlock, Business, Finance, & EconomicsRead

","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"type":"ad","heading":"ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW","name":"ArticleFirstBigBox","display":"medium-down","pos":"1","interstitial":true,"sizes":[[300,250]]},{"text":"The group’s defiant response was shared thousands of times on social media, including by prominent pundits like American conservative commentator <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://twitter.com/glennbeck/status/1495811304342306817\">Glenn Beck</a>.","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"text":"<a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://bitcoinmagazine.com/markets/bitcoin-fundraising-canada-ottawa-truckers-freedom-convoy\">According to one protest organizer</a>, 80 per cent of crypto funds raised for the convoy are held in Nunchuck wallets. ","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"text":"But despite the court’s orders to halt those transactions, independent experts say the crypto group appears to be right — Nunchuck can’t keep its users from exchanging cryptocurrency. ","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"text":"Nunchuck.io — which boasts “the safest self-custody solution for your bitcoin” on its website — designs software that allows people to store their cryptocurrency in a digital wallet they download through the group’s app. ","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"type":"ad","heading":"ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW","name":"ArticleSecondBigBox","display":"medium-down","pos":"2","interstitial":true,"sizes":[[300,250]]},{"text":"When that wallet is downloaded onto the users’ personal device, Nunchuck cannot access what’s inside, says Andreas Park, a professor of finance at the University of Toronto’s Rotman School of Management. ","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"type":"articleRelatedInlinePrimary"},{"type":"textBreakPoint","insertAt":"contentMiddleBreakPoint"},{"text":"“The same way that Google can’t just reach into your computer and uninstall Chrome,” said Park. ","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"text":"“(The court order) is a bit like writing to Bellroy, telling them to remotely apply a tool so that the button doesn’t open and wallet owners can’t take out their cash,” said Park, referring to the <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://bellroy.com/\">Australian accessories brand</a>. ","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"type":"stn-smart-player"},{"text":"As part of the injunction issued Thursday, the Ontario Superior Court ordered several financial institutions, fundraising platforms and digital asset platforms to halt all financial transactions from the bank accounts and digital wallets belonging to protest organizers.","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"text":"The order applied to TD Bank, GoFundMe, GiveSendGo and nine cryptocurrency groups including Bitbuy, TallyCoin, Shakepay and Nunchuck.","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"type":"slimcut"},{"text":"A spokesperson for Bitbuy, a cryptocurrency exchange service, told the Star in an emailed statement they will comply with the court’s order. ","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"text":"The reason Bitbuy can comply with the injunction is because it’s an exchange service — a place where users go to buy, sell and hold cryptocurrency, explained Park. Since users exchange crypto on BitBuy’s website, the company can intercept assets and freeze accounts by monitoring users’ activity. ","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"text":"“This is where court orders have some bite, because with crypto exchanges there’s a third party that has custody over your assets,” Park said. ","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"text":"Since Nunchuck is not an exchange and does not oversee cryptocurrency transactions — rather, it allows users to download software to hold their assets on their personal devices — it cannot regulate the flow of digital currency.","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"text":"“They would have no concept of the location, nature or identity of users, and if this was actually part of a court order served upon them, it would be inapplicable to them since they could not technically comply with those aspects,” said Christine Duhaime, a financial crime expert with Fusion Intelligence. ","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"type":"relatedStories","relatedStories":[]},{"text":"The Ontario Superior Court did not respond to the Star’s request for comment Tuesday morning. ","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"text":"In an email to the court on Friday, following the injunction, Nunchuck wrote: “Please look up how self custody and private keys work. When the Canadian dollar becomes worthless, we will be here to serve you, too.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"type":"cta","buttonText":"Sign Up Now","buttonLink":"/emails.html?nsrc=article-inline-business","description":"Read the business news and analysis that matters most every morning, including the latest on what the coronavirus means for you, in our Star Business email newsletter.","title":"Get more business in your inbox"},{"text":"A Nunchuck spokesperson told the Star it has not heard from the court since, and declined to comment further.","type":"text","isParagraph":true,"isHeading":false},{"text":"Lawyer Paul Champ, acting on behalf of a group of Ottawa residents that launched a class-action lawsuit against the protest organizers, said the plaintiffs are “very aware of (Nunchuck’s) online statements” but declined to comment further. class="primary-label-basic"><a href="/business.html"><div class="label-flag label-pointer label-color-primary">Business</div></a></div></div><h1 class="c-article-headline__heading c-article-headline__heading--long">Crypto group protests court order to freeze trucker convoy accounts — says it ‘cannot’ freeze money or prevent it from being moved</h1><h2 class="c-article-headline__abstract">Independent experts say cryptocurrency group Nunchuck appears to be correct — it does not have the power to control digital wallets or access what’s inside.</h2></header><div class="article__byline__font c-article-header__byline article__byline-container-author-withphoto" data-lpos="article|author"><div class="article__img-container"><div class="c-author-badge article-byline__author-badge"><img class="c-author-badge__img" src="https://images.thestar.com/psaKwU-e7CBPI4unRjiBEj4OL1I=/100x100/smart/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/columnist_logos/Lorinc_Jacob_logo2019new.JPG" alt="Jacob Lorinc" aria-hidden="true"/></div></div><div class="article__byline"><span class="article__author-by">By </span><span class="article__author"><span class="article__author-name"><span><span><a href="/authors.lorinc_jacob.html"><span>Jacob Lorinc</span></a></span></span></span><span class="article__author-credit">Business Reporter</span></span><div class="article__time-container"><span class=""><span class="article__published-date">Tue., Feb. 22, 2022</span></span><span class="published-date-border"></span><span class="article__readtime"><i class="material-icons-outlined c-material-icon c-material-icon--article-readtime-clock" role="img" pointer-events="none" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true">timer</i><span>3<!-- --> min. read</span></span></div></div></div><div class="conversation-indicator-container c-article-header__conversations"><div class="conversation-container"><span class="c-conversation-indicator-icon"></span><span class="c-conversation-indicator-text"><span>JOIN THE CONVERSATION </span><div class="viafoura conversation-replies-count"><span class="vf-counter vf-widget" data-widget="counter" data-path="/business/2022/02/22/crypto-group-protests-court-order-to-freeze-trucker-convoy-accounts-says-it-cannot-freeze-money-or-prevent-it-from-being-moved.html" data-unique_id="f7990764-e39a-4bf7-966d-1c1e33be7b79"></span></div></span></div></div></div><div class="c-article-body" data-lpos="article|body"><div class="c-article-body__content"><p class="text-block-container">A cryptocurrency group whose software was used to funnel bitcoin to the “freedom convoy” in Ottawa says it cannot fulfil an Ontario judge’s order to freeze accounts associated with the protest, testing the legal system’s ability to curtail the flow of digital currency. </p><p class="text-block-container">On Friday, after Ontario Superior Court Justice Calum MacLeod <a class="text-block__link" onContextMenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)"href="https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2022/02/17/citizens-group-wins-court-ordered-freeze-of-freedom-convoy-accounts-cryptocurrency.html">granted an injunction to a private citizens’ effort</a> to stop funding for the protest — including more than $1 million in bitcoin — crypto exchange Nunchuck.io said that it “cannot” freeze its users money or prevent it from being moved because it does not have access to their digital wallets. </p><p class="text-block-container">“We cannot ‘freeze’ our users’ assets. We cannot ‘prevent’ them from being moved. We do not have knowledge of ‘the existence, nature, value and location’ of our users’ assets. This is by design,” the group wrote <a class="text-block__link" onContextMenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)"href="https://twitter.com/nunchuk_io/status/1494885897577271299/photo/1">in a tweet</a>, showing a screenshot of an emailed response they claim to have sent to the court. </p><p class="text-block-container">The group’s defiant response was shared thousands of times on social media, including by prominent pundits like American conservative commentator <a class="text-block__link" onContextMenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)"href="https://twitter.com/glennbeck/status/1495811304342306817">Glenn Beck</a>.</p><p class="text-block-container"><a class="text-block__link" onContextMenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)"href="https://bitcoinmagazine.com/markets/bitcoin-fundraising-canada-ottawa-truckers-freedom-convoy">According to one protest organizer</a>, 80 per cent of crypto funds raised for the convoy are held in Nunchuck wallets. </p><p class="text-block-container">But despite the court’s orders to halt those transactions, independent experts say the crypto group appears to be right — Nunchuck can’t keep its users from exchanging cryptocurrency. </p><p class="text-block-container">Nunchuck.io — which boasts “the safest self-custody solution for your bitcoin” on its website — designs software that allows people to store their cryptocurrency in a digital wallet they download through the group’s app. </p><p class="text-block-container">When that wallet is downloaded onto the users’ personal device, Nunchuck cannot access what’s inside, says Andreas Park, a professor of finance at the University of Toronto’s Rotman School of Management. </p><div class="article-related-inline"></div><span style="display:block" id="contentMiddleBreakPoint"></span><p class="text-block-container">“The same way that Google can’t just reach into your computer and uninstall Chrome,” said Park. </p><p class="text-block-container">“(The court order) is a bit like writing to Bellroy, telling them to remotely apply a tool so that the button doesn’t open and wallet owners can’t take out their cash,” said Park, referring to the <a class="text-block__link" onContextMenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)"href="https://bellroy.com/">Australian accessories brand</a>. </p><div class="stn-smart-player-component" tabindex="0" aria-label="video player powered by sendtonews"></div><p class="text-block-container">As part of the injunction issued Thursday, the Ontario Superior Court ordered several financial institutions, fundraising platforms and digital asset platforms to halt all financial transactions from the bank accounts and digital wallets belonging to protest organizers.</p><p class="text-block-container">The order applied to TD Bank, GoFundMe, GiveSendGo and nine cryptocurrency groups including Bitbuy, TallyCoin, Shakepay and Nunchuck.</p><p class="text-block-container">A spokesperson for Bitbuy, a cryptocurrency exchange service, told the Star in an emailed statement they will comply with the court’s order. </p><p class="text-block-container">The reason Bitbuy can comply with the injunction is because it’s an exchange service — a place where users go to buy, sell and hold cryptocurrency, explained Park. Since users exchange crypto on BitBuy’s website, the company can intercept assets and freeze accounts by monitoring users’ activity. </p><p class="text-block-container">“This is where court orders have some bite, because with crypto exchanges there’s a third party that has custody over your assets,” Park said. </p><p class="text-block-container">Since Nunchuck is not an exchange and does not oversee cryptocurrency transactions — rather, it allows users to download software to hold their assets on their personal devices — it cannot regulate the flow of digital currency.</p><p class="text-block-container">“They would have no concept of the location, nature or identity of users, and if this was actually part of a court order served upon them, it would be inapplicable to them since they could not technically comply with those aspects,” said Christine Duhaime, a financial crime expert with Fusion Intelligence. </p><div class="article-related-inline"></div><p class="text-block-container">The Ontario Superior Court did not respond to the Star’s request for comment Tuesday morning. </p><p class="text-block-container">In an email to the court on Friday, following the injunction, Nunchuck wrote: “Please look up how self custody and private keys work. When the Canadian dollar becomes worthless, we will be here to serve you, too.”</p><p class="text-block-container">A Nunchuck spokesperson told the Star it has not heard from the court since, and declined to comment further.</p><p class="text-block-container">Lawyer Paul Champ, acting on behalf of a group of Ottawa residents that launched a class-action lawsuit against the protest organizers, said the plaintiffs are “very aware of (Nunchuck’s) online statements” but declined to comment further. </p><span style="display:block" id="contentEndBreakPoint"></span><p class="text-block-container">The case returns to court on Monday.</p><div class="author-endnote-container border-bottom" data-lpos="article|author|bottom"><a class="author-endnote-container__author-img-link" href="/authors.lorinc_jacob.html"><div class="c-author-badge author-endnote-container__author-img"><img class="c-author-badge__img" src="https://images.thestar.com/psaKwU-e7CBPI4unRjiBEj4OL1I=/100x100/smart/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/columnist_logos/Lorinc_Jacob_logo2019new.JPG" alt="Jacob Lorinc" aria-hidden="true"/></div></a><div><a class='author-endnote-container__author-link' href='/authors.lorinc_jacob.html'>Jacob Lorinc</a> is a Toronto-based reporter covering business for the Star. Reach him via email: <a href="mailto:jlorinc@thestar.ca">jlorinc@thestar.ca</a></div></div><div class="related_topics" data-lpos="article|related-topics"><strong>Read more about: </strong><div readabilityObject.title: Crypto group protests court order to freeze trucker convoy accounts — says it ‘cannot’ freeze money or prevent it from being moved
readabilityObject.content:
Independent experts say cryptocurrency group Nunchuck appears to be correct — it does not have the power to control digital wallets or access what’s inside.

A cryptocurrency group whose software was used to funnel bitcoin to the “freedom convoy” in Ottawa says it cannot fulfil an Ontario judge’s order to freeze accounts associated with the protest, testing the legal system’s ability to curtail the flow of digital currency.

On Friday, after Ontario Superior Court Justice Calum MacLeod granted an injunction to a private citizens’ effort to stop funding for the protest — including more than $1 million in bitcoin — crypto exchange Nunchuck.io said that it “cannot” freeze its users money or prevent it from being moved because it does not have access to their digital wallets.

“We cannot ‘freeze’ our users’ assets. We cannot ‘prevent’ them from being moved. We do not have knowledge of ‘the existence, nature, value and location’ of our users’ assets. This is by design,” the group wrote in a tweet, showing a screenshot of an emailed response they claim to have sent to the court.

The group’s defiant response was shared thousands of times on social media, including by prominent pundits like American conservative commentator Glenn Beck.

According to one protest organizer, 80 per cent of crypto funds raised for the convoy are held in Nunchuck wallets.

But despite the court’s orders to halt those transactions, independent experts say the crypto group appears to be right — Nunchuck can’t keep its users from exchanging cryptocurrency.

Nunchuck.io — which boasts “the safest self-custody solution for your bitcoin” on its website — designs software that allows people to store their cryptocurrency in a digital wallet they download through the group’s app.

When that wallet is downloaded onto the users’ personal device, Nunchuck cannot access what’s inside, says Andreas Park, a professor of finance at the University of Toronto’s Rotman School of Management.

“The same way that Google can’t just reach into your computer and uninstall Chrome,” said Park.

“(The court order) is a bit like writing to Bellroy, telling them to remotely apply a tool so that the button doesn’t open and wallet owners can’t take out their cash,” said Park, referring to the Australian accessories brand.

As part of the injunction issued Thursday, the Ontario Superior Court ordered several financial institutions, fundraising platforms and digital asset platforms to halt all financial transactions from the bank accounts and digital wallets belonging to protest organizers.

The order applied to TD Bank, GoFundMe, GiveSendGo and nine cryptocurrency groups including Bitbuy, TallyCoin, Shakepay and Nunchuck.

A spokesperson for Bitbuy, a cryptocurrency exchange service, told the Star in an emailed statement they will comply with the court’s order.

The reason Bitbuy can comply with the injunction is because it’s an exchange service — a place where users go to buy, sell and hold cryptocurrency, explained Park. Since users exchange crypto on BitBuy’s website, the company can intercept assets and freeze accounts by monitoring users’ activity.

“This is where court orders have some bite, because with crypto exchanges there’s a third party that has custody over your assets,” Park said.

Since Nunchuck is not an exchange and does not oversee cryptocurrency transactions — rather, it allows users to download software to hold their assets on their personal devices — it cannot regulate the flow of digital currency.

“They would have no concept of the location, nature or identity of users, and if this was actually part of a court order served upon them, it would be inapplicable to them since they could not technically comply with those aspects,” said Christine Duhaime, a financial crime expert with Fusion Intelligence.

The Ontario Superior Court did not respond to the Star’s request for comment Tuesday morning.

In an email to the court on Friday, following the injunction, Nunchuck wrote: “Please look up how self custody and private keys work. When the Canadian dollar becomes worthless, we will be here to serve you, too.”

A Nunchuck spokesperson told the Star it has not heard from the court since, and declined to comment further.

Lawyer Paul Champ, acting on behalf of a group of Ottawa residents that launched a class-action lawsuit against the protest organizers, said the plaintiffs are “very aware of (Nunchuck’s) online statements” but declined to comment further.

The case returns to court on Monday.
